On Thursday 03 July 2003 18:40, Paul Prescod wrote:
> But you could _separately_ make an engineering argument that it would be
> more useful if there were multiple resources.

I am making the engineering argument. I am arguing about how to
design RESTful applications.

> My rule of thumb is that the thing has multiple resources behind it if
> you have to invent a new addressing scheme to talk about the things, and
> you start embedding those addresses in XML documents or passing them
> around as parameters to APIs etc.

A username is an identifier that exists in an address space
separate from the URI address space.

> > As for the original example, if the application is designed
> > without user-specific resource URLs, it will not be possible to
> > even link to cities created by other users. Ah well, foreign
> > travel is overrated anyways.
>
> I would presume that every city has its own URL and the only question is
> whether every user is allowed to see every city or whether they get an
> authorization complaint.

You can only make this presumption if there is an established and
adhered to convention that it is RESTless to do otherwise. Are you
ready to declare so?

> > 1. REST states that important resources should have a URI.
>
> Great.

I was very surprised to read that Roy does not agree with us. See:

On Friday 04 July 2003 12:13, Roy T. Fielding wrote:
> REST does not claim that all important resources must have identifiers.

Roy, are you saying that the "must" is a "should"? I used
"should", not "must". If you wish to even further weaken the
constraint, I think you should provide clear and objective
guidance on when an important resource need not have an
identifier. If you have already done so, please provide a link.

On Thursday 03 July 2003 18:40, Paul Prescod wrote:
> > 2. A user-specific resource is an important resource.
>
> Great.

If you accept points 1 and 2, the argument is made. Points 3 to 5
simply draw out the consequences of 1 and 2. Given points 1 and 2,
it is RESTless to not give a user-specific resource a URI.

> > 3. HTTP Auth is used to discriminate between user-specific
> > resources.
>
> HTTP auth can be used to do two things. One is to disallow access to a
> resource. The other is to personalize a resource. Let's say I send you a
> URL for a site that we both have accounts for (Slashdot is a perfect
> example). It shows up for you with a blue background because of a
> preference you set and it shows up as green for me. This is good from a
> usability point of view: you are seeing the information as you asked for
> it and I am seeing it as I asked for it. It is the same resource.

Again, I am not arguing against container URLs. I am arguing
against the absence of user-specific URLs.

I am also not arguing that Slashdot should actually implement a
user-specific URL for its home page. I am only arguing that it is
RESTless for Slashdot to not do so. In this case, it is likely
that this RESTless design will have no negative consequences.
This result will not always be the same. The more "important" the
resource, the more likely it is that RESTless design will have
negative consequences. RESTless design of a less "important"
resource may go unnoticed.

I suspect that RESTless design is more of a problem in a web
service than in a web site. A web site may have many appearance
variation resources that are not present in a web service.

Clear rules help us identify potential design problems and avert
them. This is the basis for engineering. You seem to be taking the
stance that a feel-good "anything goes" ruleset should be used.
This leaves REST without a real model or way of evaluating
designs.

It is OK to call things RESTless and still use them. However, if
you are unable to correctly categorize designs, you reduce your
ability to improve your designs. Let's drop the squeamishness
around calling things RESTless.

Tyler
